answers.author: Sam Anselm
answers.text:
Social media, city website, a news release to your media contacts. If you have a connection with the schools, that's always a good resource as well. We're currently engaging our residents to complete a parks survey, and we've been successful (so far) using these methods. Don't be afraid to sound like a broken record, because your audience may not hear the message if you only put it out there once, or via a single method.

answers.author: Cory Fleming
answers.text:
If you've got the staff and/or volunteer time to do it, I think going to where people are is a good strategy.  For example, table tents in area restaurants, information booths outside the local grocery stores, flyers in the bleachers at local baseball games, etc.

answers.author: Cheryl Hilvert
answers.text:
Hi Michelle!  Sam raised some great ideas to inform your community about your survey.  You may also consider out reach to your various community, service,  and civic organizations  (homeowners' associations, business organizations, Rotary/Kiwanis Clubs) as well as to the faith-based organizations in your community.  Additionally, face-to-face opportunities can be created by having local government representatives visit the local pool, coffee shops, little league events with reminder cards.  This is a great opportunity to put a "face" on your local government as well.  
The important thing to remember about your engagement efforts is that they should be both multi-faceted (online, mail, face-to-face, etc.) and multi-sector (involving a variety of organizations and opportunities to reach the community.  For more information on great approaches to engagement, visit the Center for Management Strategies Articles and Documents resource listing at icma.org/strategies

answers.author: Philip Freeman
answers.text:
Michelle,
We recently wanted to drum up publicity for a citizen survey. We got in touch with the local newspaper, who ran a brief story online -- next thing I knew, the local TV news channel, a radio host, and another local news source contacted us to learn about (and promote) the survey. Even though it was not the most exciting story, it seemed that every news outlet wanted to be "in the know" about the survey!

answers.author: Michael Spafford
answers.text:
I realize this is a little late, but if you are near an accredited MPA program, there may be possibility for collaboration. When attending the University of Dayton, our stats class conducted a resident survey for a nearby City. The City paid for the printing and delivery, but had access to 10 graduate students and our professor for statistical analysis and presentation.
